rule.name: www_2nms-2nd_alt
rule.comment: URL, with protocol and 3rd-level name and a subpage and no port. However, the 2nd level domain name is spoken as a word. Covers the following 2nd level names: "co", "gov", "mod", "net", "org", "police". www.store.amazon.co.uk -> w w w ponc store ponc amazon ponc co ponc u k

rule.name: www-2nd_alt
rule.comment: URL, with protocol and 3rd-level name and no subpages and no port. However, the 2nd level domain name is spoken as a word. Covers the following 2nd level names: "co", "gov", "mod", "net", "org", "police". www.edinbugh.gov.uk -> w w w ponc edinbugh ponc gov ponc u k

rule.name: www_2nms-2nd
rule.comment: URL, with protocol and 3rd-level name and no subpages and no port. www.inf.ed.ac.uk -> w w w ponc inf ponc ed ponc ac ponc u k

rule.name: www-2nd
rule.comment: URL, with protocol and 3rd-level name and no subpages and no port. www.ed.ac.uk -> w w w ponc ed ponc ac ponc u k

rule.name: www_2nms_alt
rule.comment: URL, with protocol no 3rd-level name and a sub-domain name but no port number. However, the TLD is spoken as a word, e.g. "com". Must come before rule "www_2nms" to be effective. www.sport.spiegel.com -> w w w ponc sport ponc spiegel ponc com

rule.name: www_alt
rule.comment: URL, with protocol no 3rd-level names and no subpages and no port. However, the TLD is spoken as a word, e.g. "com". Must come before rule "www" to be effective. www.gov.scot -> w w w ponc gov ponc scot

rule.name: www_2nms
rule.comment: URL, with protocol no 3rd-level name but a sub-domain-name and no subpages and no port. www.sport.spiegel.de -> w w w ponc sport ponc spiegel ponc d e

rule.name: www
rule.comment: URL, with protocol no 3rd-level names and no subpages and no port. www.amazon.com -> w w w ponc amazon ponc com

rule.name: http
rule.comment: Covers "http://" by transforming it into "h t t p ~colon ~slash ~slash". http:// -> h t t p idirstad slais slais

rule.name: file_names_pdf
rule.comment: When strings ending in a dot followed by a well known file suffix, the file name is spoken as word and the file suffix as single characters. document.pdf -> document ponc p d f

rule.name: file_names_doc
rule.comment: When strings ending in a dot followed by a well known file suffix which is spoken as word, both parts are spoken as words. document.doc -> document ponc doc

rule.name: currency_last_pre
rule.comment: Last resort rule for single token currency (such as USD25.03) We leave the handling of the number for later. USD10 -> deich dollar na stát aontaithe

rule.name: currency_last_post0

rule.name: currency_last_post
rule.comment: Last resort rule for single token currency (such as 25.03USD) We leave the handling of the number for later. 10USD -> deich dollar na stát aontaithe

rule.name: currency_signs

rule.name: currency_signs2b

rule.name: between_1_measure_11to19_measure_split

regex.name: precedes_numbers_d_apostrophe
regex.comment: Prepositions that cause vowels to take a d' de ocht -> d'ocht

regex.name: precedes_numbers_seimhiu
regex.comment: Prepositions that cause words to take a séimhiú

regex.name: precedes_numbers_uru
regex.comment: Prepositions that cause words to take an urú

regex.name: precedes_numbers_uru_an
regex.comment: Prepositions that cause words to take an urú when followed by an e.g. ag an mbord

regex.name: file_name_pdf
regex.comment: List of file suffixes which are spoken as single characters. Taken from: http://www.fileinfo.com/common.php

regex.name: file_name_doc
regex.comment: List of file suffixes which are spoken as a word. Taken from: http://www.fileinfo.com/common.php

regex.name: upper_case_2_4
regex.comment: For acronyms, identified by being case strings of length two to four. Extend with language-specific characters. Checking for the signs at the end are necessary as we are checking "T-00"...

regex.name: word_2_4
regex.comment: For acronyms, identified by being case strings of length two to four. Extend with language-specific characters.

regex.name: upper_case_2dotted
regex.comment: Covers cases like "S.A." Doesn't match A.M. or P.M. to avoid conflicting with time rules

regex.name: max_04_digits_colon
regex.comment: Used for years. Up to four digits, with maximal three leading "0"s.

regex.name: time_at
regex.comment: For catching times preceded by at/around. TODO - translate "around"

regex.name: area_code
regex.comment: The area code of a telephone number. Start with "0" followed by 2 to four digits, with the second not a "0".

regex.name: float_0d_postcomma_cur
regex.comment: Covers the case where the digit after the comma is a zero.

regex.name: month_name_two_words_first
regex.comment: Used for matching months with two word names

regex.name: month_name_two_words_second
regex.comment: Used for matching months with two word names

regex.name: year
regex.comment: Covers the years from 1000 to 9999. The feature of being able to say "sixteen hundred twenty one" is handled accessing groups "$02" for the "century" part and "$03" for the "ten" part. Normal numbers are stored in "$00".

regex.name: year_ad
regex.comment: Covers the years from 1000 to 9999. The feature of being able to say "sixteen hundred twenty one" is handled accessing groups "$02" for the "century" part and "$03" for the "ten" part. Normal numbers are stored in "$00".

regex.name: year_bc
regex.comment: Covers the years from 1000 to 9999. The feature of being able to say "sixteen hundred twenty one" is handled accessing groups "$02" for the "century" part and "$03" for the "ten" part. Normal numbers are stored in "$00".

regex.name: measure_masc
regex.comment: May need to remove single character ones, e.g. m, t, w, etc.

regex.name: number_currency
regex.comment: match any kind of number / currency

regex.name: number_currency_pre
regex.comment: match any kind of number / currency

regex.name: number_currency_post
regex.comment: match any kind of number / currency

regex.name: telephone_ssml_generic_strict
regex.comment: telephone_ssml_generic_full is too generic. Need at least two groups of numbers

regex.name: strip_right_bracket
regex.comment: Strip punctuation and replace with break

regex.name: time_pm_zero_irish
regex.comment: Stricter format as 6in is the Irish for 6PM, so has to be 6:00in

regex.name: punc_strip
regex.comment: Important: DO NOT REMOVE It is used by the normaliser to remove punctuation from the tokens (t-XX). If you want to access the punctuation, use the token T-XX.

regex.name: punc_strip_full
regex.comment: Important: DO NOT REMOVE It is used by the normaliser to remove punctuation from the tokens (t-XX). This is a recursive variant of the previous regex; it will split the input tokens recursively to remove the punctuation. If you want to access the punctuation, use the token T-XX.

regex.name: separators
regex.comment: Important: DO NOT REMOVE It is used by the tokeniser to tokenise these characters separately

regex.name: alpha
regex.comment: Important: Do not delete this regex, as it is used by the normaliser internally. Also, extend it with the language-specific letters.

regex.name: whitespace
regex.comment: Overide default to regard hypens as wspace until norm rules added to deal with hypenation.

lookup.name: lowercase
lookup.comment:
Important: Do not delete this table, as it is used by the normaliser internally. Also, extend it with the language-specific letters. Lowercase variants should be entered. Specific repetitions (such as "www":"w w w") may also be entered.
Letters in Irish are read as English, so force use of [lex entry] for letter lookups as many individual letters can be words in Irish.
Letters j, k, q, v, w, x, y, z are not used in Irish, so can only be entry_letter
